item.title: UK universities draw up plans for EU campuses ahead of Brexit
item.content:encoded:
Higher education chiefs, struggling with uncertainty and challenges in regulation and funding, look to soften blow of EU exit

British universities are considering plans to open branches inside the European Union in an effort to soften the blow of Britain’s exit, as they struggle to navigate new challenges in regulation and funding.

Related: Bricks and mortar boards: UK universities embark on major building schemes

Continue reading...

item.title: UK economy faces challenging period after Brexit vote, says Bank
item.content:encoded:
Financial policy committee warns withdrawal from the EU poses risks but will not be used to reduce regulation of banks

The vote for Brexit has created a “challenging period of uncertainty and adjustment” Bank of England policymakers have said.

In a quarterly update on the health of the financial system on Thursday, the Bank’s policy makers also said the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union would not be used as a way to reduce regulation on the banking sector.

Continue reading...

item.title: Lloyd's considers opening EU subsidiary to be ready for Brexit
item.content:encoded:
Insurance market working on ‘contingency plan’ so it can continue trading across Europe once article 50 is triggered

Lloyd’s of London is looking at opening an office in another EU state to protect its insurance underwriting business from the impact of the UK’s Brexit vote.

Lloyd’s confirmed on Thursday that the world’s oldest insurance underwriting market was drawing up a contingency plan that could be implemented as soon as Theresa May’s government triggers article 50 to begin formal negotiations to leave the EU, which is expected early next year.

Continue reading...

item.title: Mortgage lending climbed in August, says CML
item.content:encoded:
Figures show resilience of housing market despite fears of crash following vote to leave EU

Gross mortgage lending hit its highest August level since before the financial crash, figures show, as the housing market appeared to defy fears of a crash after the Brexit vote.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) said its members had advanced a total of £22.5bn during the month, 7% higher than July’s figure and up 15% year on year.

Continue reading...

item.title: PM holding talks on smoothing Brexit process
item.content:encoded: Theresa May will host the President of the European Parliament in Downing Street, as she seeks to smooth the path of Brexit talks.

item.title: Labour has no option but to hold together | Jonathan Reynolds
item.content:encoded:
History is littered with examples of failed breakaway parties. A split is out of the question if we are to challenge Conservative hegemony

Labour has a had a torrid time of late. Since last summer the tone of the party’s internal debate has been shrill and bitter. Views have become increasingly polarised, and speculation about a possible split commonplace. We have been likened to a couple who want to divorce but who choose to stay together because we cannot afford to sell the house. Now the polls have closed and, in the aftermath of Jeremy Corbyn’s anticipated victory on Saturday, people will almost certainly again raise the question of whether Labour should simply split and let its warring factions walk away from each other.

Related: Get serious, Labour rebels, and deal with the Brexit catastrophe | Polly Toynbee

Continue reading...

item.title: Brexit is risking student numbers and vital research funding, says head of Oxford University after it is named world's best
item.content:encoded: The institution's Vice Chancellor says other universities are already trying to poach her academics

item.title: Supermarkets plan to shrink packets and use cheaper ingredients to save money after Brexit
The Brexit economy: post-referendum data defies gloomy UK predictions
item.content:encoded:
Guardian analysis of key economic figures gives rounded assessment three months after the vote

• Help fund our journalism by becoming a Guardian supporter

Related: How has the Brexit vote affected the UK economy? September verdict

Fears that Britain will slide into a post-referendum recession have been allayed after a Guardian analysis showed the latest news on the economy has confounded analysts’ gloomy expectations, with consumer spending strong, unemployment low and the housing market holding steady.

Continue reading...

item.title: Newspaper headlines: MoD Afghanistan inquiry, Brexit gloom 'defied' and columnists on Brangelina split
item.content:encoded: An inquiry into alleged abuses by UK troops in Afghanistan and reports on the post-Brexit economy attract headlines.

item.title: Boris Johnson never wanted Brexit and only backed Leave to become 'heir apparent' to Tory throne, says minister
item.content:encoded: In a BBC documentary to be broadcast this week the Foreign Office Minister claims the now Foreign Secretary, who was his boss, wanted Brexit to lose

item.title: With a Brexiteer in charge, the UK's ghastly, hypocritical, wasteful aid policy might change. And I say that as a Remainer
Brexit: UK economy faces uncertain future after shock referendum result, say two independent reports
item.content:encoded: Expert forecasts come in midst of political party conference season - in which country's fortunes outside the EU are the central theme.

item.title: Voters showing no signs of ‘buyer’s remorse’ over Brexit, top pollster says
Brits in the EU: are you applying for citizenship?
item.content:encoded:
If you live or work in an EU country and are applying for citizenship due to the Brexit vote, we want to hear from you

After Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, British citizens living and working across the EU have been weighing up their futures.

Related: Zero chance EU citizens in UK will keep same rights post-Brexit, says expert
